claim: People in Japan are richer than people in Mexico.

supporting.text: Japan has a higher GDP per capita than Mexico, indicating greater average individual wealth.

attacks.text: Japan has a higher GDP per capita than Mexico, indicating greater average individual wealth.
GDP per capita does not account for wealth inequality, and Japan has significant income disparity that may not reflect the financial reality of most citizens.
Japan's Gini coefficient (measure of income inequality) is lower than Mexico's, suggesting wealth is more evenly distributed in Japan.
Cost of living in Japan is significantly higher than in Mexico, so higher nominal GDP per capita may not translate to higher purchasing power or quality of life.
Purchasing power parity (PPP) adjustments show Japan's GDP per capita remains higher than Mexico's even after accounting for cost of living differences.
Informal economy in Mexico is large and unmeasured by GDP statistics, meaning actual wealth may be undercounted.
Japan's informal economy is among the smallest in OECD countries, making its GDP per capita figures more comprehensive and reliable for comparison.

supporting.text: The median household income in Japan is significantly higher than in Mexico.

attacks.text: The median household income in Japan is significantly higher than in Mexico.
Median income does not account for cost of living differences, which are higher in Japan.
Even accounting for cost of living, purchasing power parity (PPP) data still shows higher disposable income in Japan.
Income inequality in Japan is lower than in Mexico, so median income comparisons may not reflect typical wealth distribution.
Lower inequality in Japan strengthens the claim, as it means more people are near the higher median income level.
Non-monetary factors like access to healthcare and education are better indicators of wealth than income alone.
Japan also outperforms Mexico in healthcare and education metrics, supporting the broader wealth comparison.

supporting.text: Japan has a lower poverty rate compared to Mexico, suggesting fewer people live in financial hardship.

attacks.text: Japan has a lower poverty rate compared to Mexico, suggesting fewer people live in financial hardship.
Poverty rate alone does not account for wealth distribution; Japan might have a smaller wealth gap but lower median income compared to Mexico.
Japan's median household income is significantly higher than Mexico's, reinforcing the claim that people in Japan are generally richer.
Cost of living in Japan is much higher than in Mexico, so nominal income comparisons may not reflect actual purchasing power.
Even adjusted for purchasing power parity (PPP), Japan's GDP per capita remains substantially higher than Mexico's.

supporting.text: The cost of living in Japan is higher than in Mexico, but average wages are also substantially higher, leading to greater disposable income.

attacks.text: The cost of living in Japan is higher than in Mexico, but average wages are also substantially higher, leading to greater disposable income.
While average wages are higher in Japan, income inequality is also greater, meaning many Japanese citizens may not actually have higher disposable income than Mexicans.
Income inequality measures in Japan are actually lower than in Mexico, meaning the higher average wages more accurately reflect typical disposable income.
The higher cost of living in Japan may offset the wage difference, leaving little actual advantage in disposable income.
Studies show that even accounting for cost of living, net disposable income remains significantly higher in Japan due to superior public services and lower necessary expenses.

supporting.text: Japan's advanced economy and technological infrastructure contribute to higher overall wealth compared to Mexico's developing economy.

attacks.text: Japan's advanced economy and technological infrastructure contribute to higher overall wealth compared to Mexico's developing economy.
Wealth distribution in Japan is highly unequal, with significant poverty among certain demographics, which may not make all Japanese richer than Mexicans.
Japan's social welfare programs and minimum wage policies help mitigate income inequality, ensuring a higher baseline standard of living than in Mexico.
Mexico has a large informal economy that is not captured in GDP statistics, potentially underrepresenting the actual wealth of its population.
The informal economy in Mexico often involves low-paying, unstable jobs, which do not significantly raise the overall wealth compared to Japan's formal sector.

supporting.text: Mexico has a larger informal economy, which often results in lower reported incomes and less financial security for many workers.

attacks.text: Mexico has a larger informal economy, which often results in lower reported incomes and less financial security for many workers.
Japan has a higher cost of living, which can offset higher nominal incomes, reducing the actual purchasing power of Japanese workers.
Even with a higher cost of living, Japan's social safety nets and access to quality services (healthcare, education) ensure a higher standard of living for most citizens.
The informal economy in Mexico includes many small businesses and self-employed individuals who may earn substantial unreported income, improving their actual wealth.
Unreported income in the informal economy often lacks stability and access to credit, limiting long-term financial security compared to formal employment.
